urn:contentItem:5V7S-N661-JD34-V2JH-00000-00Truck fire at Bears Lagoon: Firefighters on scene2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisTruck fire at Bears Lagoon: Firefighters on sceneEmma D'Agostino

UPDATE, 4.03pm: A TRUCK fire at Bears Lagoon has been brought under control.

A CFA spokesperson said crews from Jarklin and Serpentine were still on scene, trying to extinguish the flames.

They said Forest Fire Management Victoria has been requested to assist in relation to a number of trees in the area.

The CFA spokesperson said there was a lot of black smoke in the area.

There was no injury to the truck driver, they said.

EARLIER: FIREFIGHTERS are responding to a truck fire at Bears Lagoon, north of Bendigo.

A CFA spokesperson said the situation was contained, but the truck was well alight.

Crews are expected to be at the scene for some time.

Firefighters were called to a truck stop at Bears Lagoon, near the intersection of the Loddon Valley Highway and Borung-Prairie Road, about 2.45pm today.

The CFA spokesperson said the fire spread to nearby vegetation, but was being attended to.

A tanker from Jarklin was on scene in two minutes. A tanker from Serpentine is also responding.

The truck's driver was out of the vehicle and was speaking with CFA members.

urn:contentItem:5MS4-S401-F0J6-J0XR-00000-00By Esther LauakiFourteen fire...2017-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisAPg. 3By Esther LauakiFourteen fire...

By Esther Lauaki

Fourteen fire trucks and a helicopter took two hours to bring a 10-hectare grass fire under control at a Riddells Creek property last week.

CFA crews from Riddells Creek, Gisborne and Sunbury were called to the fire at McDonalds Lane after a tractor sparked flames while slashing grass on the property.

Fire crews were later joined by Macedon, Mount Macedon, Clarkefield, Bolinda-Monegeetta, Bullengarook, Romsey, Wildwood and Hesket-Kerrie brigades.

Riddells Creek Fire Brigade Captain Tom Morley said using a helicopter had been critical in preventing the spread of the fire.

"As the fire spread to a nearby gully, it became difficult for firefighters to attack the fire and this is where the helicopter was instrumental," Mr Morley said.

"These smaller four-wheel drive fire trucks also played a critical role in stopping the spread of the fire."

Meanwhile, the burn-off of a 100 square metre pile of branches and leaves on the Clyde Track at Mount Macedon earlier this month sparked concerns about communication.

Forest Fire Management Victoria issued a public advisory notice on the Calder freeway about smoke being visible in the area.

But the Country Fire Authority's Mt Macedon group officer Ian Hay said he was not told, and raised his concern over what he said was "a breakdown in communication" after he heard about the burn-off from a member of the public.

But Mt Macedon CFA captain Jim Darby said the brigade had been informed about the burn-off. He said the communication breakdown was within the Mt Macedon fire brigades group - the body that oversees local brigades in the Macedon Ranges area.

â€‹"Because of the late time in the season (to burn off), the decision would have been made late Monday or Tuesday, but word got to us," Mr Darby said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Midlands district manager Jasmine Filmer said telephone contact had been made with the CFA district 2 duty officer on Monday to advise of the intended burn-off, along with a pager message to Macedon and Kyneton brigade members.

urn:contentItem:5X12-0SC1-F0J6-J36R-00000-00Minimising the risks of bushfire2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisMinimising the risks of bushfire

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are introducing fire restrictions for East Gippsland Shire, starting from 1am on Monday, September 23 and continuing until May 1, 2020 unless stated otherwise.

CFA's Assistant Chief Officer South East, Trevor Owen and FFMVic Deputy Chief Officer, Beth Roberts said that restrictions are being enforced early again in East Gippsland to minimise the risk of grass and bushfires being started by private burn-offs and escaped campfires in the current dry conditions.

"The seasonal bushfire outlook for this year has focused on East Gippsland as the driest part of the state, with three years of lower than normal rainfall and drought conditions across much of the region," Mr Owen said.

"Our forest fuels are tinder-dry and it wouldn't take much of a spark from a burn-off or an unattended campfire to start a bushfire.

"CFA and FFMVic crews had a huge season last summer and we want to minimise the risk of another, or worse this summer."

Ms Roberts said both fire services were well-prepared to respond to the threat of bushfire with additional firefighters, new equipment and infrastructure, and an expanded aircraft fleet.

"The community needs to be fire ready early too - especially those living in high risk areas. Fire restrictions are in place for a reason - to help prevent fires from starting," she said.

"It's critical that residents understand and comply with these fire restrictions to help to prevent bushfires like the ones we saw earlier this year."

The Chiefs urged residents to make preparation for fire a habit, so they are not caught unprepared when bushfires strike.

"Prepare your property, prepare yourself and prepare your family for fire. Have a fire plan in place and most importantly, practise it," Mr Owen said.

To find out more about getting ready for the fire season visit www.cfa.vic.gov.au or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5TPV-M691-F0J6-J2FJ-00000-00Fuel reduction burns planned in Walmer State Forest2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Fuel reduction burns planned in Walmer State Forest

Fuel reduction burns will be carried out in the Walmer State Forest on Tuesday, with smoke likely to be visible from Castlemaine and Harcourt

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA have advised that the following planned burning will be carried out tomorrow, weather conditions permitting:

National Fire Investigation Training - Barkers Creek: Fuel reduction burn, 24.2 hectares, 3.5 kilometres north west of Castlemaine in the Walmer State Forest.

National Fire Investigation Training - Castlemaine : Fuel reduction burn, 10.3 hectares, 2.5 kilometres north west of Castlemaine in the Walmer State Forest.

The burns should be completed between 9am and 8pm hours on Tuesday, November 13, however smoke may be visible until Friday, November 16.

The fires will also be used by Fire Investigation Training to help hone investigative skills as part of a bushfire course.

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering

urn:contentItem:59NC-1KJ1-F0J6-J1XG-00000-00'Cool' fires can be part of the forest fire solution2013-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSOpinionPg. 39'Cool' fires can be part of the forest fire solutionRoss Hampton

There is a better ways of reducing the intensity of bush fires, and using forestry to fight fires may be one of them. Ross Hampton

Hey @AdamBandt - here's a tip, fight fire with forestry. The conversation Mr Bandt wants to have about the long-term effects of climate change on the frequency and intensity of bush fires is worthwhile.

But we must also discuss the best way to reduce bush-fire intensity.

The process at present is pretty simple.

Step 1. Lock up the bush.

Step 2. Minimise activities that reduce the number and density of trees and fallen branches - be it hazard reduction burning or thinning of some areas, and building access roads.

Step 3. Cross fingers and pray no idiots start fires and lightning does not strike.

Step 4. When a bush fire inevitably starts and, because of all the fuel, becomes a raging wildfire, ignore all the rules of step 1 and 2, frantically back-burn, and rush in the bulldozers.

Surely, this is crazy.

There is a better way but it challenges those people with a simplistic view of the world that puts "natural conservation areas" in one camp, and "multiple-use forestry" in another.

Who can possibly count the loss from the NSW fires? How many trees and animals were incinerated in the name of conservation? And what of air quality and emissions? These fires have already added nearly 3.5million tonnes of carbon dioxide to Australia's emissions for this year and where is the "environmentalism" in that?

During the election campaign, the Prime Minister announced that $15million would be directed into a "national bush-fire mitigation program".

We will argue strongly that this should mean a lot more than hazard reduction burns. Certainly "cool" fires are part of the solution, but what about fighting fire with at least some more forestry?

In the United States five months ago, a massive Arizona fire killed 19 firefighters.

In the last month another huge blaze - the Rim Fire - roared through the historic Yosemite National Park, burning the largest area in centuries.

John Buckley, the executive director of the Central Sierra Environmental Resource Centre, told Reuters if the US national park service had a tree-thinning process, it "would have unarguably made the Rim Fire far easier to contain, far less expensive and possibly not even a major disaster".

In Australia, Monash University researcher David Packham said reducing fuel loads in the Australian bush was an urgent issue.

Phil Cheney, a former head of CSIRO bush fire research, has found "fire intensity is far more significantly affected by fuel quantity, fuel dryness and wind strength than it is by temperature''.

In the US they have had enough and are getting serious about fuel reduction. The US Forest Service is a using reduction burning and forestry thinning to remove excess fuel.

Are we listening?

Our Rural Fire Service does an amazing job but this a largely volunteer force made up of committed people with day jobs. Despite bundles of commitment and as much training as can be squeezed in, this valiant work is essentially trying to close the door on a bolting horse.

AFPA hopes to persuade Prime Minister Tony Abbott when it comes to the bush fire prevention fund, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

And preservation is not a binary proposition.

Perhaps @AdamBandt can agree?

Ross Hampton is CEO of the Australian Forest Products Association

urn:contentItem:5V4J-DJ91-JD3N-52CH-00000-00Escape from inferno2019-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Escape from inferno

BRAVE firefighters have told how they were forced to retreat from the fierce Rosedale blaze as authorities revealed it could burn for weeks.

The group - the first to respond to the suspicious fire which continued to burn last night - said it started near a cabin-like building about 200m from bushland and "took off".

Rosedale brigade member Phil Davison said the heat was so intense the crew had to pull back and immediately called another 10 tankers.

"If we had have gone into it in the trucks it would have melted the trucks," he said.

The close encounter came just hours before dozens of firefighters from two CFA brigades and forest fire management were left shaken when the unpredictable fire front turned on them.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said the group of about 40 firefighters was working on the fire's eastern flank late Friday when a wind change forced them to take cover.

"They found themselves in a very serious situation and they were shaken as a result of it," Mr Crisp said.

A truck, trailer and a bulldozer were destroyed in the incident which will now be investigated.

Arson chemists examined the scene yesterday, but the cause of the fire - which has claimed more than 10,000ha of land - had not yet been established.It was yesterday downgraded to the least serious fire warning.

urn:contentItem:49KD-1F10-01S8-G4M1-00000-00<published>1987-10-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:29:09Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>REAL PLANTS TO CUT NZ'S EXPO FOREST FIRE RISK</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>RODGERS S</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Real plants to cut NZ's Expo forest fire risk By Expo reporter SHANE RODGERS DESIGNERS of the New Zealand pavilion for World Expo 88 will use real plants and metal foilage to modify their artificial rainforest after a fire two weeks ago. The pavilion deputy consul-general, Mr Tony Briscoe, said a problem with new artificial foliage used in the trees had now been identified. That foliage would be replaced. Details were also released yesterday of more living world effects at the exhibit, including a waterfall entrance and a hydraulic moving theatre floor in a woolshed theatre. The floor's motion is designed to tantalise the senses of children watching jet-boating, skiing and ballooning films. Mr Briscoe said the public had nothing to fear in the forest. All artificial trees would contain smoke detectors. They were lined with concrete as an added precaution against fire. ""We're even running fire tests on the trunks themselves to reassure ourselves that they are safe," he said. ""What you have to remember is that at the moment it is a construction site. Once everything is running there will be a permanent mist in the forest and things will be fairly damp all the time." Mr Briscoe said the fire cost the New Zealand Government about $15,000 plus down-time for cleaning up and rebuilding. It started when a welder accidently ignited one of the fibreglass trees. While visitors to the pavilion will leave via the artificial rainforest, the entrance will be a six-metre high waterfall.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>It will take up the entire front facade. The water will part every 15 minutes and allow about 200 people to begin a New Zealand experience. This will include a spectacular slide show projected on to the back of the waterfall. Visitors will enter a theatre where they will hear a Maori myth while they are surrounded by what designers describe as a living world of water and undersea life. The Maori storyteller will be seen on a mist screen, giving the presentation a multi-screen hologram effect. In another part of the pavilion, projection techniques will help ice sculptures of famous New Zealanders come to life.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5WXF-P0W1-JD3N-526S-00000-00Fire risk looms in state's east2019-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Fire risk looms in state's eastALEX WHITE

GIPPSLAND is facing a dangerous fire season this summer following a very dry winter.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp has revealed Victoria's east is looking at an above average season although the rest of the state has been rated as normal risk.

"The severity of fires in Victoria will still depend on several factors including the amount, location and timing of rain in the months leading up to and including over summer," he said.

"Much of Gippsland has now experienced three consecutive years of significant low rainfall in autumn and winter." According to the Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook, drier conditions are also having impacts in the west with a risk that ash forests in the Central Highlands and Otways may dry out faster, increasing the risk over summer.

Mr Crisp said the emergency management sector was preparing ahead of the summer season.

"Pre-season briefings for emergency management -personnel will begin to rollout across Victoria so our people understand the outlook, know the risks and are prepared to respond to emergencies, and work with communities," he said.

"While emergency management agencies are preparing, it's also important the community understands their own risk and is actively preparing. This is a shared responsibility." Forest Fire Management Victoria acting chief fire -officer Chris Eagle said emergency management agencies would be keeping an eye on any change in conditions.

"The outlook is a good early indication of what we will expect in the upcoming summer season and will be updated later in the year as predictions firm up," he said.

CFA chief officer Steve Warrington said there would be fires in Victoria this summer. "We urge our farmers across the state to take care while harvesting and storing crops and hay in the coming months to avoid fires caused by machinery and self-combusting haystacks," he said.alex.white@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:5XGP-C0P1-F0JP-W3X2-00000-00Locals join NSW battle2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Locals join NSW battleOLIVIA REED, with AAP

LOCAL firefighters are among more than 450 CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) members fighting bushfires in NSW.

CFA firefighters from districts six and seven, which cover Colac and Geelong, will be part of a taskforce at Goulburn as more than 60 bushfires burn across the state. A week-long state of emergency has been declared in New South Wales.

Following a request by the NSW Rural Fire Service for more aid, the CFA sent 311 personnel from across Victoria to the Hunter Region and Goulburn ahead of the predicted extreme or catastrophic weather forecast for yesterday.

FFMVic firefighters from Geelong, Anglesea, Barwon Downs and Colac were also part of a taskforce that left on Friday. The 18-person taskforce, based at Glen Innes on the Northern Tablelands, had been tasked to the Gulf Road fire in the Torrington area and will return to Victoria today.

More than 150 FFMVic firefighters and emergency management support personnel have been sent to the NSW bushfires over the past month. Staff also flew further north yesterday to provide emergency management support during the Queensland bushfires.

Specialist personnel from FFMVic's Geelong, Anglesea and Colac offices are among a multi-agency contingent requested by the Queensland Government.

CFA state duty officer John Katakouzinos said in the ongoing bushfire emergency it was important for interstate crews to lend a hand. The CFA has also dispatched a fleet of 55 tankers and 21 operational support vehicles.

FFMVic Barwon South West regional agency commander Hamish Martin said the taskforce had been protecting properties, and had saved a number of homes.

"These firefighters are working through extreme heat, smoke, gusty winds and flying embers as they do their best to keep communities safe from harm," he said.

"We're proud of our firefighters who have flown interstate to take on very difficult and often confronting tasks, dedicating their time and skills to protecting communities during this devastating time."Three people have died and 100 injured in the blazes, including 20 firefighters.

urn:contentItem:5MH3-WK81-JC0X-K01N-00000-00VIC:No NYE Melbourne terror threat: police2016-12-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:No NYE Melbourne terror threat: policeMELBOURNE Dec 29

  There is no intelligence that suggests Melbourne will be the target of a terror attack on New Year's Eve, police say.
   There will be a strong police and ambulance presence in the CBD to support the half a million Melburnians expected to flock in for end of year celebrations, but police say they have completely "neutralised" all links to an alleged terror plot.


   "We know people might be concerned about the events of last week," Victoria Police Commander Russell Barrett said of raids that resulted in four men in their 20s being charged over an alleged plot to bomb a Melbourne landmark on Christmas Day.
   "We want to reassure the Victorian community that there is no known intelligence and we have neutralised the threat."
   Police will deploy a large number of officers to curb crowd crush, anti-social behaviour, drug-taking and drink driving, Commander Barrett said on Thursday.
   Outside the city, Forest Fire Management Victoria officers are focused on shutting down illegal rave parties on public land.
   Two events planned to attract several hundred people at Big River and Buckland Valley have already been shut down this month.
   Forest Fire Management investigator Samantha Moore said some organisers or illegal raves fail to patrons' safety into account.
   "Consideration is not given to important controls such as first aid requirements, dangerous trees, toilet and litter facilities, accessibility for emergency services in the event of an incident or bushfire," Ms Moore said.
   Public Transport Minister Jacinta Allen encouraged people to utilise the free public transport service to get in and out of the CBD and around the state safely between 6pm on New Year's Eve and 6am on New Year's Day.
   About 65 per cent of the people coming into the city will use public transport, Ms Allen said.
   Lord Mayor Robert Doyle said he was, as always, nervous about the number of people who were expected to come into the city but he was confident the meticulous, year-long planning would ensure it would be a great event.
   "Last year we had two arrests. I think that's a remarkable tribute to the city," Mr Doyle said.

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4N70-0048-T08K-00000-00<published>1997-09-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:29:09Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VIC: FOREST FIRE SHOWS EXTENT OF DROUGHT</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">- FIREFIGHTERS BUSHFIRES VIC    MELBOURNE, Sept 30 AAP - The first major bushfire in Victoria<br/> was a concern as it showed the extent of drought in the state, fire authorities said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> of Dartmoor, 20 km from the South Australian border, Department of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE) acting chief fire officer Richard Alder said.</p><p>Firefighters from NRE contained the fire by building control lines around it and backburning the unburnt sections adjacent to the tracks, they said.</p><p> NRE fire controller Andrew Morrow said 12 NRE fireghters attended the fire with four tankers and a bulldozer involved in the effort.</p><p> "Firefighters are continuing to black out and patrol the fire and will remain at the site until it is declared safe to leave," Mr Morrow said.</p><p> The cause of the fire would be investigated, he said.</p><p> "The relatively large size of this fire is of concern because it indicates the potential impact of months of dry conditions experienced across the state before this month's rain," Mr Alder said.</p><p> "We urgently need follow-up rain on the forest fuels if any early start to the fire season is to be delayed," he said.</p><p> He said the weather was mild with light winds yesterday "yet, as this fire demonstrated, the forest fuels are conducive to the rapid spread of fire", he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4N70-0048-T08K-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="222"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5JHJ-DJB1-JD67-11WB-00000-00Planned burn at Deep Lead2016-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPlanned burn at Deep Lead

THE Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning and Parks Victoria will carry out a 47-hectare burn planned burn north of Stawell on Wednesday, conditions permitting.

The Deep Lead-Three Jacks Track burn two kilometres north of Stawell will provide fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the size and intensity of bushfires occurring north of Stawell.

'Because of its proximity to Stawell, this burn has been timed to minimise the impact of smoke on the town,' Forest Fire Management Wimmera District Manager Russell Manning said.

'We have been keeping the community and visitors updated, all landholders within close proximity of the burn have been given burn notification cards and a messaging board has been placed on highway.

'We have also asked the Department of Health and Human Services to distribute smoke information to anyone who may need it.

'The Stawell brigade has been briefed and we have invited them to participate.

'Carrying out this burn in early autumn means we also avoid overlapping with the germination period of a rare orchid species. This decision has been endorsed by the Australian Native Orchid Society.

'The weather is the biggest challenge for the planned burn program. We can only burn when the weather, and conditions like wind, temperature and fuel moisture levels are right.

'Planned burning is a vital part of the fuel reduction work conducted throughout the year by highly skilled fire crews from Forest Fire Management and our partners.'

The chief fire officer currently has final approval on all planned burns.

This measure is in place as the department changes its approach to risk management in response to the recommendations of the Lancefield-Cobaw Fire Investigation.

urn:contentItem:5XGF-DF81-F0JP-W3W6-00000-00No end in sight for deadly fires2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4No end in sight for deadly firesJOSH FAGAN

VICTORIAN fire crews have been sent in to help tackle the deadly New South Wales bushfires as the state braces for a day of catastrophic fire -danger.

Authorities have warned of devastating conditions that could intensify out of control fires which have already claimed three lives and razed more than 200 homes and sheds.

Almost 500 Victorian firefighters have been deployed to fire-ravaged regions, including strike teams in Singleton and Goulburn.

A seven-day state of emergency was declared in NSW yesterday - the first since the 2013 Blue Mountains fires.

NSW Emergency Services Minister David Elliott said residents were facing what "could be the most dangerous bushfire week this nation has ever seen".

The forecast of extreme heat and gale-force winds has been likened to the conditions of Victoria's Black Saturday in 2009, when 173 people were killed.

Temperatures in the high 30s, winds over 80kmh and low humidity were expected to make it virtually impossible for firefighters to control the worst fires, from Sydney's north coast down to Hawkesbury, Lithgow and the Blue Mountains.

Crews from the CFA, MFB, SES and Forest Fire Management Victoria were brought in as part of a major deployment to add back-up and support for their NSW counterparts.

Victoria's State Duty Officer John Katakouzinos said the focus was on trying to minimise damage amid fears of more loss of life and destruction of property.

He said it was important to pitch in and lend a hand in the face of a dire emergency.

"We would like to thank not only the firefighters who give up their time to protect lives and properties in NSW, but also the families, loved ones and businesses that allow our members to assist with this emergency," he said.

The CFA dispatched a fleet of 76 vehicles and 286 firefighters, who drove up or were flown in. The military was placed on standby to send thousands of national troops to help the bushfire crisis with commanders ordered to deploy local troops to combat the unprecedented catastrophic wildfire threat.josh.fagan@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:5XF0-6GP1-JD34-V1YS-00000-00Call for care as danger period looms2019-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Call for care as danger period loomsElspeth Kernebone

FIREFIGHTERS have called on people to comply with fire danger period regulations, warning that human activity caused most fires.

It followed the Country Fire Authority declaring Bendigo's fire danger period will begin on November 11.

To the north, Campaspe and Loddon shires both entered their fire danger period on Monday November 4, following several fires in the region last week.

CFA District 2 commander Chris Jacobsen said people caused the majority of fires.

Mr Jacobsen said Bendigo's forests were dry and grasses were curing, despite the rain over the weekend. He said the area was starting to see fires.

But Mr Jacobsen said it took an ignition source to start a fire. He said the coming fire danger period's outcome depended on the behaviour of the public, even on cooler days.

"It's human activity that causes the majority of our fires. You can have fuels and different conditions. But if you don't have the ignition source you don't have fires," Mr Jacobsen said.

"The restrictions are in to prevent ignition of fire. Because we're now in the period, in the wrong conditions fires can get away and damage property or injure, and even potentially kill, people."

Mr Jacobsen warned that private burn-offs at the start and end of the season caused the most problems for firefighters. He urged anyone burning-off to put fires out with water, monitor them, and have a three metre break.

The CFA warned residents to use common sense when burning-off last week, following many calls to out-of-control burn offs.

The start of this year's fire danger period will be several weeks later than the 2018 period, which was the earliest start for the district in more than 20 years. Mr Jacobsen said the start date was based on the conditions and curing of the grassland.

Forest Fire Management Victoria regional manager of fire and emergency preparedness Carsten Nannestad said the organisation was recruiting firefighters, burning off and servicing machinery ahead of the fire season.

The fire danger period begins across Greater Bendigo on Monday November 11 at 1am. More at: bit.ly/2PIzJrx

urn:contentItem:5N8H-S5W1-JD34-V4N2-00000-00Watch and Act warning for Rupanyup grassfire2017-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisWatch and Act warning for Rupanyup grassfireRex Martinich

UPDATE: 4:45pm

Firefighters have stopped the spread of a grassfire at Rupanyup - Brynterion road 10 kilometres south of Rupanyup.

The fire is not yet under control but the incident has been downgraded to the 'advice' level.

"The spread of the fire has been stopped and CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are continuing to build a mineral earth break around the fire," the Country Fire Authority stated.

"The fire has burnt around 100 hectares and fire crews will remain on the fire ground for several hours.

"Currently no properties or communities are at risk."

4pm

The Country Fire Authority has issued a 'Watch & Act' warning for Rupanyup and Rupanyup South for a grassfire at Rupanyup-Brynterion Road, about 10 kilometres south of Rupanyup.

As of 4pm on Saturday the the fire was not under control and had burnt 100 hectares so far.

Firefighters are also battling smaller fires at Lillimur, Miriam, Lawloit, Peronne, Goroke, Gymbowen, Chetwyn, Conniewirricoo, Brooksby State Forest, Wal Wal, Lah, Telopea Downs and the Big Desert at Yanac.

Severe thunderstorm warning for damaging winds and large hailstones has also been issued in the Wimmera.

"Houses and assets to the south and east of Brynterion State Forest should activate their fire plan and be aware of a south westerly wind change expected later this afternoon," the warning stated.

"CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria and aircraft are attending this fire.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

At least 11 fire units are currently on the scene at Rupanyup.

An Advice message is being issued for Big Desert, Telopea Downs, Waggon Flat, Yanac, Broughton and Netherby.

"There is a bushfire at Big Desert Yanac Red Bluff Track in the Big Desert Wilderness that is not yet under control," the message stated.

"The bushfire is travelling in a north-westerly direction towards Waggon Flat.

"There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions."

The next update is expected 6.20pm Saturday or as the situation changes.

urn:contentItem:5MFC-KSW1-F0J6-J31V-00000-00More eyes in the sky for fire season2016-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisMore eyes in the sky for fire seasonEllen Ebsary

A further line of defence in tackling fires across the North East will be operational within weeks.

The new Mount Barambogie tower will be ready as soon as the cabin is hoisted on this week.

It replaces the Mount Pilot tower, nine kilometres to the East, which was not used during the 2015 fire season due to safety reasons.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse said the former structure needed to be replaced due to the lightning protection system failing standards.

"We'd originally planned to start towards the end of September and in the end we made a start in the first week of November. We're three weeks behind our original finish date."

urn:contentItem:5N8H-S5W1-JD34-V4MP-00000-00Watch and Act warning for Rupanyup grassfire2017-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisWatch and Act warning for Rupanyup grassfireRex Martinich

UPDATE: 4:45pm

Firefighters have stopped the spread of a grassfire at Rupanyup - Brynterion road 10 kilometres south of Rupanyup.

The fire is not yet under control but the incident has been downgraded to the 'advice' level.

"The spread of the fire has been stopped and CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are continuing to build a mineral earth break around the fire," the Country Fire Authority stated.

"The fire has burnt around 100 hectares and fire crews will remain on the fire ground for several hours.

"Currently no properties or communities are at risk."

4pm

The Country Fire Authority has issued a 'Watch & Act' warning for Rupanyup and Rupanyup South for a grassfire at Rupanyup-Brynterion Road, about 10 kilometres south of Rupanyup.

As of 4pm on Saturday the the fire was not under control and had burnt 100 hectares so far.

Firefighters are also battling smaller fires at Lillimur, Miriam, Lawloit, Peronne, Goroke, Gymbowen, Chetwyn, Conniewirricoo, Brooksby State Forest, Wal Wal, Lah, Telopea Downs and the Big Desert at Yanac.

Severe thunderstorm warning for damaging winds and large hailstones has also been issued in the Wimmera.

"Houses and assets to the south and east of Brynterion State Forest should activate their fire plan and be aware of a south westerly wind change expected later this afternoon," the warning stated.

"CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria and aircraft are attending this fire.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

At least 11 fire units are currently on the scene at Rupanyup.

An Advice message is being issued for Big Desert, Telopea Downs, Waggon Flat, Yanac, Broughton and Netherby.

"There is a bushfire at Big Desert Yanac Red Bluff Track in the Big Desert Wilderness that is not yet under control," the message stated.

"The bushfire is travelling in a north-westerly direction towards Waggon Flat.

"There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions."

The next update is expected 6.20pm Saturday or as the situation changes.

urn:contentItem:5WVH-YH01-F0JP-W0RG-00000-00Tree deaths trigger alert2019-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Tree deaths trigger alertAndrew Rogers andrew.rogers@news..com.au

People are being urged to contact a Yarra Ranges Council hotline if they fear the safety of trees in the wake of two deaths in the hills.

A woman was killed on August 9on the Black Spur section of the Maroondah Highway in the Yarra Ranges National Park while driving her family to a snow trip.

Angie Suryadi planned the trip to celebrate the birthday of her husband, Arnold Aditiasvara, who was injured in the incident.

Their son, Oliver, 4, remains in a critical condition at the Royal Children's Hospital, while their other son, Johnathon, 5, was not seriously injured. The tragedy followed the death of a 46-year-old man and 10-year-old boy, believed to be a Cockatoo father and his son, who were killed when a falling tree crushed their car in the Dandenong Ranges National Park in Sherbrooke last month.

Trees in state forests and national parks are managed by the State Government's Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning and Parks Victoria.

The council's director of environment and engineering, Mark Varmalis, said effective management of trees depended on members of the community reporting any concerns. "We respond to a large number of tree requests from residents, who may have concerns about the health of a tree or potential risk of falling," he said. "These requests are all inspected by qualified arborists and any subsequent recommended works are prioritised based on the urgency of the situation." Maurice Blackburn principal lawyer Alison Barrett called for an urgent safety audit of all trees on public land to avoid future tragedies. A Forest Fire Management Victoria spokeswoman, who refused to be named, said the state's forest and national parks were home to hundreds of millions of trees.Tree hotline: 1300 368 333.

urn:contentItem:5F1B-X7H1-F031-X55N-00000-00Police seeking information about campfire suspected to have started Bago State Forest fire2015-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisPolice seeking information about campfire suspected to have started Bago State Forest fire

Police have confirmed they believe campers started a fire last weekend which burnt 700 hectares of the Bago State Forest.

Forestry officials are hoping to salvage some of the pine trees for processing in Tumut.

Detective Inspector Paul Huxtable says any anonymous information about the campers would be welcomed by police but he would also hope those responsible would hand themselves in.

He says police do not believe their actions equate to arson.

"I have seen a few things on Facebook so obviously there was someone thereabouts at the time," he said.

"So if a number of people chip in with little bits of information it very quickly turns into a bit of a picture that we can act upon.

"Looking at the incidents of South Australia, the devastation that bushfires can cause, the part of the world we're looking at near Blowering Dam is very hilly, very thick with trees, so the potential for something really nasty is quite high.

"The thoughts we have is the people there were camping and enjoying the lake as many people do.

"Perhaps they've started a fire, it got out of control and they may have fled purely for their own safety.

"So if you're the person who started that fire, we're keen to talk to you to establish the origin of the fire, how it happened and how we can prevent this in the future."

The Cootamundra Local Area Command's Crime Manager says police want to speak to those responsible, just to ensure the fire cause is clear.

"From the information we've gathered it would look as though that is the cause of the origin and it's the nature of campers they try to find an isolated spot," Detective Inspector Huxtable said.

"So that's the challenge we've got at the moment is trying to pinpoint who these people were.

"So if there's anyone who was about at the area and saw something they think might be only mildly suspicious, certainly the police are very interested in speaking with them."

Meanwhile, the Victorian Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning says 74 campfires were found still burning in the Hume and Murray regions last week.

Hume Region Manager, Tony Long, says there were total fire bans in place on Friday and Saturday and several people are now facing fines.

He says campers must make sure campfires are completely out before leaving any area.

"Fuel like red gum continues to burn for a long period of time," he said.

"You must extinguish fires with water, the general rule is if it's safe to touch with the back of your hand then it's safe to leave but you must spend a lot of time extinguishing the fire and around where you have been burning."

Mr Long says not being aware of a total fire ban is not an excuse, and fires should not be lit during extreme conditions.

"They were very hot dry days and we would certainly be questioning the need for why people would need fires at all on days like that," he said.

"So people should be definitely be listening to the radio if their out in the bush, if they haven't got radio it's the precautionary principle, don't light it if it's a hot dry day."

urn:contentItem:5XF0-6GP1-JD34-V1XY-00000-00Call for care as danger period looms2019-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisCall for care as danger period loomsElspeth Kernebone

FIREFIGHTERS have called on people to comply with fire danger period regulations, warning that human activity caused most fires.

It followed the Country Fire Authority declaring Bendigo's fire danger period will begin on November 11.

To the north, Campaspe and Loddon shires both entered their fire danger period on Monday November 4, following several fires in the region last week.

CFA District 2 commander Chris Jacobsen said people caused the majority of fires.

Mr Jacobsen said Bendigo's forests were dry and grasses were curing, despite the rain over the weekend. He said the area was starting to see fires.

But Mr Jacobsen said it took an ignition source to start a fire. He said the coming fire danger period's outcome depended on the behaviour of the public, even on cooler days.

"It's human activity that causes the majority of our fires. You can have fuels and different conditions. But if you don't have the ignition source you don't have fires," Mr Jacobsen said.

"The restrictions are in to prevent ignition of fire. Because we're now in the period, in the wrong conditions fires can get away and damage property or injure, and even potentially kill, people."

Mr Jacobsen warned that private burn-offs at the start and end of the season caused the most problems for firefighters. He urged anyone burning-off to put fires out with water, monitor them, and have a three metre break.

The CFA warned residents to use common sense when burning-off last week, following many calls to out-of-control burn offs.

The start of this year's fire danger period will be several weeks later than the 2018 period, which was the earliest start for the district in more than 20 years. Mr Jacobsen said the start date was based on the conditions and curing of the grassland.

Forest Fire Management Victoria regional manager of fire and emergency preparedness Carsten Nannestad said the organisation was recruiting firefighters, burning off and servicing machinery ahead of the fire season.

The fire danger period begins across Greater Bendigo on Monday November 11 at 1am. More at: bit.ly/2PIzJrx

urn:contentItem:5XD4-9PT1-F0J6-J35J-00000-00Pistol, drugs seized in police raid as man cops 10 charges2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisPistol, drugs seized in police raid as man cops 10 chargesBreanna Chillingworth

A PISTOL, other weapons and drugs have been seized, and a man is behind bars on a raft of charges after an undercover operation near Tamworth.

Stephen Oliver appeared in Tamworth Local Court on Thursday on 10 separate drug and guns charges after a raid in Willow Tree earlier this week.

He did not enter pleas to the charges and was refused bail by magistrate Julie Soars.

The 31-year-old was arrested at Tamworth police station on Wednesday morning by police from Strike Force Burchmore after presenting for questioning.

READ ALSO:

38 troops plus an air tanker: Extra firepower for wild forest fire Kevin Anderson doesn't give a dam to doubling Dungowan size Delays 'not out of the ordinary' as murder accused denied bail The Western Region Enforcement Squad - which is based in Tamworth - setup the strike force in June to home in on those involved in the supply of methylamphetamine in the Willow Tree and Quirindi areas.

After months of investigations, officers swooped on Tuesday, raiding a Learmonth Street home in Willow Tree.

Police allege they uncovered a pistol, ammunition, a crossbow, drugs suspected to be methylamphetamine, as well as cannabis plants and other prohibited drugs.

The goods were seized at the scene by officers.

Oliver was arrested at 8.55am on Wednesday and questioned by investigators before being charged.

He's accused of supplying more than an indictable quantity of drugs; cultivating a prohibited plant; suspected stolen goods in custody; possessing an unauthorised prohibited firearm, as well as a prohibited weapon without a permit; possessing ammunition; not keeping a prohibited firearm safely; and two counts of possessing prohibited drugs, as well as a restricted substance.

The most serious charge - possessing an unauthorised prohibited firearm - carries a maximum of 14 years' imprisonment, if found guilty.

After Thursday's court appearance, Oliver was transferred into the custody of Corrective Services NSW and will remain behind bars until he returns to court in Tamworth in mid-November.

Investigations by Strike Force Burchmore are continuing.

urn:contentItem:5XD4-9PT1-F0J6-J39V-00000-00Pistol, drugs seized in police raid as man cops 10 charges2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Pistol, drugs seized in police raid as man cops 10 chargesBreanna Chillingworth

A PISTOL, other weapons and drugs have been seized, and a man is behind bars on a raft of charges after an undercover operation near Tamworth.

Stephen Oliver appeared in Tamworth Local Court on Thursday on 10 separate drug and guns charges after a raid in Willow Tree earlier this week.

He did not enter pleas to the charges and was refused bail by magistrate Julie Soars.

The 31-year-old was arrested at Tamworth police station on Wednesday morning by police from Strike Force Burchmore after presenting for questioning.

READ ALSO:

38 troops plus an air tanker: Extra firepower for wild forest fire Kevin Anderson doesn't give a dam to doubling Dungowan size Delays 'not out of the ordinary' as murder accused denied bail The Western Region Enforcement Squad - which is based in Tamworth - setup the strike force in June to home in on those involved in the supply of methylamphetamine in the Willow Tree and Quirindi areas.

After months of investigations, officers swooped on Tuesday, raiding a Learmonth Street home in Willow Tree.

Police allege they uncovered a pistol, ammunition, a crossbow, drugs suspected to be methylamphetamine, as well as cannabis plants and other prohibited drugs.

The goods were seized at the scene by officers.

Oliver was arrested at 8.55am on Wednesday and questioned by investigators before being charged.

He's accused of supplying more than an indictable quantity of drugs; cultivating a prohibited plant; suspected stolen goods in custody; possessing an unauthorised prohibited firearm, as well as a prohibited weapon without a permit; possessing ammunition; not keeping a prohibited firearm safely; and two counts of possessing prohibited drugs, as well as a restricted substance.

The most serious charge - possessing an unauthorised prohibited firearm - carries a maximum of 14 years' imprisonment, if found guilty.

After Thursday's court appearance, Oliver was transferred into the custody of Corrective Services NSW and will remain behind bars until he returns to court in Tamworth in mid-November.

Investigations by Strike Force Burchmore are continuing.

urn:contentItem:52H4-FF61-JD3N-521W-00000-00Forest fire sale could cost state up to $1bn2011-03-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 33Forest fire sale could cost state up to $1bnNIGEL AUSTIN, RURAL EDITOR

A BLACK hole of up to $1 billion may eventuate if South Australia pursues a fire sale of South-East forests owned by Forestry SA.

Speaking at the Senate inquiry into the Sale of Timbers Assets by the SA Government, Senator Nick Xenophon said he was concerned a loss of up to $1 billion to SA could result from a quick fire sale of the forests.

Senator Xenophon said he feared the State Government would not get the right price for the forests because it didn't appear to be factoring in the value of increasing land values, water rights, carbon and the rising value of forests.

``They could be short-changing the state by hundreds of millions of dollars,'' Senator Xenophon said.

Forestry consultant Dr Jerry Leech said the forests were being used to support the state's AAA credit rating and he was concerned the sale would undermine the credit rating.

``I'd suggest the SA Government should suggest Super SA should invest in Forestry SA because it doesn't make any sense to sell it,'' he said.

``If you sell the forest it would be in the interests of the buyer to sell the water licence, log the trees and let the land revert to scrub.''

Gunns Timber Products Green Triangle Business Group general manager David Ford said the problem was creating uncertainty which was affecting investment.

``If Gunns is unable to determine that the right environment exists in the Green Triangle, it will select a radiata pine region to support the investment of a modern high-technology sawmill,'' Mr Ford said.

``As a major employer and economic contributor to the Green Triangle region, it will have a devastating impact to local communities if Gunns exit the region.''

Gunns employs 295 people in the Green Triangle and contributes $115 million annually to the local economy in terms of raw material purchases and operational costs.

``It has created an uncertain investment environment in the region that is already impacting the confidence of local communities, depressing housing prices and undermining investments by all businesses operating in the local community,'' Mr Ford said.

NF McDonnell and Sons owner Ian McDonnell said he bought 90 per cent of his timber from Forestry SA and he feared for the future of his business if it was sold to a foreign buyer.

Mt Gambier Chamber of Commerce executive officer Lynette Martin said businesses were apprehensive about the future because of the uncertainty caused by the proposed forest sale.

``Apprentices are being handed back to authorities, building workers are getting less work and there is a lot of concern,'' she said.

urn:contentItem:5XCG-GFB1-F0J6-J013-00000-00Worry over car fires in forest as fire season approaches2019-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Worry over car fires in forest as fire season approachesHayley Elg

A firefighter has voiced his concern over the prevalence of cars fires in the region as the weather continues to warm up.

It comes after a car was set alight at Glen Park just before 2pm on Monday afternoon.

The Toyota corolla was set alight on a track in the middle of the forest, with two stringy bark trees catching fire.

Three brigades - Glen Park, Invermay and Ballarat City - and Forest Fire Management Victoria attended to bring the fire under control.

Lieutenant Brian Webber of Glen Park Fire Brigade said the brigade had responded to more than 20 car fires in the area this year.

With the fire season approaching he said it was "dangerous" as the fires could ignite surrounding bushland.

"On the right day with low moisture and high winds the fire could go anywhere. It is a worry going into the fire season," he said.

Lieutenant Webber said the car fires were occurring at all hours and were not only a "dead set nuisance" and a waste of resources but also endangered the whole community.

"The CFA is all volunteer so we have to leave our jobs or whatever else we are doing to attend these fires. It also ties us up from attending something like a house fire, so a brigade further away would be called to attend," he said.

"Car fires are totally wrong. The [offenders] have no consideration for other people's property and hard work to buy their vehicles."

A Ballarat Police spokesperson said the matter was being investigated.

He said with the upcoming fire season police were also concerned about the number of car fires in that area and urged any bush walkers who see suspicious activity to call 000.

Anybody who has information about today's car fire is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5RX2-9TX1-F0J6-J00P-00000-00Rain relief on the way as late-season heatwave ends2018-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Rain relief on the way as late-season heatwave endsPeter Hannam | Environment editor

The burst of late-season heat that seared south-eastern Australia over the weekend will give way to days of heavy showers for Sydney with bigger falls forecast for coastal regions to the north.

The falls, though, will likely be minimal over bushfire-hit parts of the NSW South Coast where a forest fire danger index reached a record high for March, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

Sydney on Monday fell shy of hitting three consecutive March days of 30 degrees - which would have been the first such trio in the month since 1902 - with a top of 28.4 degrees.

A wind shift from the north-west that had brought warm air from central Australia to an easterly flow put a cap of temperatures.

Tuesday's forecast top of 27 degrees will make way for three days of about 23-24 degrees, with rainfall totals mounting as a low-pressure trough moves in.

Wednesday could see Sydney collect 15-25 millimetres and Thursday 25-45 millimetres, the bureau said.

"At this stage, it looks like [the trough] will have the biggest impact on the central coast and possibly even further north," said Rose Barr, at the bureau. "It is dependent on where this coastal feature develops."

Newcastle may be among the wettest locations, with 10-20 millimetres forecast for Tuesday and 90-120 millimetres on Wednesday. Thursday may also be wet, with 20-40 millimetres more possible. The heavier falls are likely to come from thunderstorms developing within the system, Ms Barr said.

Tathra, where 69 homes were destroyed and 39 damaged in Sunday's fires, won't get much rain in the system, with Thursday's 2-8 millimetres the most for any of the coming days.

The system is not likely to take on the form of an east coast low, Ms Barr said, noting the absence of upper-level conditions conducive to the more extreme rains and wind.

Temperatures should begin to climb again by the weekend, with tops in Sydney of 26 and 30 degrees currently forecast for Saturday and Sunday.

It's unlikely Sydney will see a repeat of last weekend's heat, which included its hottest day this late in the season - 39.4 degrees on Sunday - since 1940. Richmond had its warmest day this far into autumn on record.

The heatwave included a range of record maximum March temperatures for towns on the NSW South Coast, included 38.9 degrees at Moruya Airport and 38.1 degrees at Merimbula, the Bureau of Meteorology said. According to Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, the forest fire danger index "was the highest on record for March for most areas of the NSW South Coast from Nowra southwards, as well as far east Gippsland and parts of the Monaro" such as Bombala.

On Saturday, every eastern capital - Adelaide, Hobart, Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, and Canberra - topped 30 degrees. That was the first time in March in 53 years and the latest in the season since records started including Canberra 80 years ago, Brett Dutschke, senior meteorologist at Weatherzone, said.

urn:contentItem:5M79-KJB1-JD34-V4CB-00000-00Call for input to fire zone changes2016-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Call for input to fire zone changesSiobhan Calafiore

People living in high fire danger areas in and around Ballarat and Bendigo have the chance to have their say on changes to the fire management zones.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has used computer modelling, which takes into account information about weather, topography, vegetation and fire history, to simulate and predict the spread and impact of bushfires.

Risk landscape manager David Watson said information from the computer modelling simulations, along with local knowledge and fire experience, would help determine the bushfire risk and the resulting changes to risk-based zoning.

Fire management zones are used as a guide for fuel management works on public land. The four types of zones are asset protection zone, bushfire moderation zone, landscape management zone and planned burning exclusion zone.

Fuel treatment may be carried out through a combination of planned burning and methods such as mowing, slashing or vegetation removal.

"Changes to the fire management zones will change how frequently fire or other fuel reduction techniques may be used in a given area of public land," Mr Watson said.

"Some zones are given a higher priority due to proximity and risk to nearby communities."

He said towns such as Daylesford, Hepburn Springs, Blackwood, Trentham, Castlemaine and the Gisborne-Woodend corridor were all at high risk of bushfires, as well as areas of Ballarat and Bendigo.

"Despite the recent and continuing rainfall, an above average fire season is still anticipated across Victoria," Mr Watson said.

"It's important people who live and work in these areas have the opportunity to share their experience and knowledge with us as we work to improve the effectiveness of our fire management strategies.

"We want to hear from individuals and community groups about what they think the proposed zone changes might mean for their local areas, as well as any local knowledge about landscape values we may need to consider."

To have your say visit haveyoursay.delwp.vic.gov.au/west-central-bushfire-risk-landscape and complete the feedback form before November 25.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is looking to have the revised fire management zones finalised by the end of December.

urn:contentItem:5V86-H1P1-JD34-V037-00000-00Lake Burrumbeet will be watched over2019-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Lake Burrumbeet will be watched overGreg Gliddon

POLICE have confirmed they will step up patrols around Lake Burrumbeet, which was last year the scene of ugly hoon behaviour and saw hoards of litter during the Australia Day long weekend.

While much of the public focus has centred around the preparations for the Rainbow Serpent Festival police say they will have extra patrols around known long weekend hot spots, including the popular camping position.

Last year, the free campsite around the lake was left trashed.

Rangers who attended the site on the Monday after the long weekend found alcohol bottles and cans, food packaging, syringes and other waste strewn around the camping ground.

Inspector Dan Davison said police would be highly visible throughout the weekend

"We will have more resources on this weekend, it is the nature of this weekend," he said.

"We are certainly aware of all the issues that happened last year and certainly we'll be putting patrols and tasking in place to combat those if they one again present themselves."

Forest Fire Management Victoria Midlands District Manager, Jasmine Filmer told The Courier last year that the behaviour was unacceptable.

"It took an entire work day for a four-person crew to clean up the rubbish left at the site, which included general waste, bits of old carpet and syringes," she said

The EPA has a 24-hour pollution hotline: call 1300 372 842 (1300 EPA VIC) to report littering.

urn:contentItem:5M2M-7D31-JD34-V4K8-00000-00Extra provisions needed for bush fire2016-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisAPg. 6Extra provisions needed for bush fire

By Esther Lauaki

There'll be extra firepower on hand for Country Fire Authority crews in the Macedon Ranges this summer.

North west regional commander Mark Gilmore said a new firefighting helicopter will be available when needed, as recommended by the Victorian Bushfire Royal Commission.

The new helicopter will stand alongside 26 other aircraft servicing regions around the state, and would be dispatched from Mangalore Airport, about 90 kilometres from the Macedon Ranges near Seymour, in a bushfire emergency, Mr Gilmore said.

"They will get the same page that ground crews receive, dispatch and be arriving at fire grounds at the same time," Mr Gilmore said.

"It will give us a lot more success during the first attack and, in doing so, means volunteers can spend less time at fire grounds, and get back to the business, back to work and back to their families."

He said the advantage of this more rapid-strike approach was the much greater prospect of keeping wild fires small.

More than 40 volunteers and professional emergency workers met at a recent pre-season briefing in Gisborne - one of the many fire preparation briefings already this season.

"There has been an enormous amount of grass growth and, because of that, we are looking at a challenging year for fast-moving grass fires," Mr Gilmore said.

While the worst fire danger period is likely to be later this season because of late rains, the north and west of the state could have fire restrictions imposed within a month, he said.Starting next week, Forest Fire Management Victoria will start slashing about 1500 hectares of public land in central Victoria in preparation for the bushfire season.

Forest Fire Management Victoria district manager Paul Bates, said works have been slightly delayed this season due to recent rains.

"Reducing bushfire risk is a shared responsibility," he said. 'Reducing fuel loads on public land can only do so much - our modelling shows a significant amount of bushfire risk is on privately owned land because of thick vegetation and high populations."

Call 136 186 to report areas of concern.

urn:contentItem:5VYM-3R81-JD34-V4NW-00000-00Little rainfall keeps fire permits in place2019-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSLittle rainfall keeps fire permits in placeEllen Ebsary

Warm and dry conditions have prompted the CFA to extend the fire danger period to May 1, and residents are being warned to be cautious well beyond that date.

District 24 operations officer Mark Owens said permits were required for any burn-off within the next week.

"People see the planned burns happening and assume they are right to go and start dropping matches without having a permit," he said.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria have permits and resources to do their burns.

"Local brigades have been doing a lot of promotion to let their communities know it is still a high danger period.

"From May 1, people will not need a permit, but until we get significant rainfall the conditions will still be very dry and people need to be vigilant."

It will be the second year in a row the fire danger period has been in place until the beginning of May.

Over the next week, FFMV will be conducting fuel reduction burns in or near Granya, Tawonga, Beechworth and Cheshunt.

North of the border, the NSW Rural Fire Service declared the bush fire danger period over in the Hume and Federation areas on Tuesday.

The season included the driest winter in 60 years and the hottest summer on record.

District manager Superintendent Patrick Westwood said the Southern Border Team attended fewer local fires this year but attended many interstate deployments.

"Even though the official bush fire danger period has finished, it is not the time for people to be burning large piles of timber that will take days to go out," he said.

"Unless you are willing to remain with those piles until they are extinguished, it is much safer to wait until winter to burn the bigger piles."

urn:contentItem:5M08-JB51-JD34-V2KR-00000-00Rain causes slashing delays2016-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Rain causes slashing delaysSophie Boyd

WET spring weather has delayed Forest Fire Management Victoria's grass slashing fire preparedness program and forced a number of firewood collection areas to close.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said the grass slashing program was delayed because of heavy rain and access difficulties at sites.

He said crews were due to start the program shortly and after community consultation they would focus on land near Stawell, Dimboola, Natimuk, Cavendish and Ararat.

Mr Manning said grass slashing was a vital part of fire prevention and heavy rain had encouraged grass growth in the region.

"With heavy rain across the district there is high likelihood that many areas might need to be slashed again later in the year," he said.

"Slashing and mowing also promotes growth of native grasses, which helps to protect native vegetation stands along creeks and rivers."

Mr Manning said the wet weather had led to some fire collection areas to close after safety concerns.

"Our staff have been vigilant in their assessment of conditions and have advised that many of areas are either inaccessible due to heavy rain or track conditions are such that providing access would only damage tracks," he said.

He said the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning would not open the fire collection areas at Brynterion Plantation in Yarriambiack Shire; Pickering Track, Illawarra, in Northern Grampians Shire; Powers Creek Road, Kadnook, in West Wimmera Shire; Forest Road, Ledcourt, in Northern Grampians Shire; and Northern Grampians Road, Wartook, in Horsham Rural City.

Mr Manning said all other areas were safe for collectors.

"We believe that there are adequate supplies of firewood in these areas, of varying sizes and quality," he said.

"Unless otherwise advised, all other designated firewood collection areas will remain open until November 30."

Mr Manning asked residents to collect firewood by hand.

He said residents should also be prepared to carry the wood some distance to their vehicle.

He said it was illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence.

It is also illegal to more fire wood than the allowed amount.

urn:contentItem:5VXB-8NJ1-F0J6-J040-00000-00Campers urged to take care with fires this Easter2019-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisCampers urged to take care with fires this EasterChris Pedler

Campers in central Victoria are being advised to take care with their camp fires this Easter.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting Loddon Mallee assistant chief fire officer Paul Bates said anyone lighting fires had a responsibility to them.

"Whether you're camping, walking, riding or driving, we all have a responsibility when it comes to making sure people take care in our parks and forests," Mr Bates said.

"Never leave a campfire unattended, you must maintain a 50-metre line of sight of the campfire at all times and ensure your campfire is completely extinguished using water.

"Illegal campfires, the dumping of rubbish, damage to forest roads and vandalism is unacceptable, so we ask everyone to do the right thing to ensure the safety of themselves and other forest users."

An on-the-spot fine of up to $484 can be issued to people who don't comply with campfire rules.

A maximum penalty of up to $16,119 can be imposed if the matter is prosecuted in court.

FFM Victoria will also be conducting planned burns in the Loddon Mallee Region over Easter.

Turner Avenue in Macedon (4.5km south of Woodend) will see a 61.6 hectares fuel-reduction burn completed between April 19 and 22.

At Ridge Road, DEnver (5.5km south of Glenlyon), a fuel reduction burn of 286.7 hectares will be completed.

"Planned burns greatly reduce the impact of bushfires by minimising fuel loads, and it is critical we take every opportunity to conduct them when it is safe to do so," Mr Bates said.

For more details on planned burns and fire restrictions visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5V4P-BB91-JC0X-K274-00000-00VIC:Watch-act alert for Vic bushfire lifted2019-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Watch-act alert for Vic bushfire liftedMELBOURNE Jan 6

  Night-time water bombing will again be used to tackle a large bushfire in Victoria's east after firefighters lifted a watch-and-act warning.


   The Rosedale fire in Gippsland, which has burned through 11,000 hectares, flared on several southern fronts on Sunday and led to warnings going out to residents in the Stradbroke and Willungareas.
   But amid cooler conditions resulting in benign fire behaviour, that alert was downgraded to advice level about 8pm.
   The CFA said significant backburning operations would continue throughout the night in the Forrester Track and Swamp Track areas.
   Overnight water bombing, which occurred for the first time in Australia on Friday night, will also be used on Sunday night.
   Victoria is trialling the use of night fire suppression helicopters, which surveil the fire area in the afternoon before returning to attack the firefront.
   "These operations will be easily heard by nearby communities," the CFA warns.
   An emergency relief centre is open at Sale Baptist Church, Lot 2 Princes Highway, Sale.
   The fire, which had been moving northeast on Saturday, has burned a significant amount of pine plantation.
   So far fencing has been the only private property destroyed, authorities say, but there are concerns for native animals in the area.
   At one stage on Friday, the blaze turned on about 40 firefighters in a predicted wind change and destroyed a fire truck, trailer and bulldozer belonging to Forest Fire Management.
   A review will be conducted into how the firefighters came to be in harm's way.

urn:contentItem:5WK1-KYY1-JD34-V3F7-00000-00You may see smoke today as the result of a planned burn2019-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisYou may see smoke today as the result of a planned burn

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has advised a planned burn will be carried out from 11am this morning.

The burn will take place on 61.3ha of land at Trentham Racecourse, two kilometres south east of Trentham.

The burn will be ignited at 11am and will conclude at 8pm.

Smoke may be visible in nearby communities.

SMOKE

· If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

· Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering

ROADS

· Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke

· Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn

· For travel times and roadworks check http://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au

ACCESS TO FOREST/PARK RECREATION SITES

· Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt

· Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

STAY INFORMED

Keep up to date with planned burning at ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, on the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226 or through the Vic Emergency app.

Sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near you via ffm.vic.gov.au/pbns

Callers who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment can contact via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.

urn:contentItem:5NK8-KCG1-F0J6-J0HX-00000-00We're all left wondering after CFA shake-up2017-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 31We're all left wondering after CFA shake-up

THE fate of volunteers in Victoria's CFA has become like a remote forest fire in recent times.

The issue has been quietly burning away out of sight after flaring into public consciousness last year with big rallies and a tug-o-war linked to the federal election.

But while the flames of fury have appeared to become flickers, the Victorian Government has been working on a new fire management plan for the state.

It will result in a new organisation Fire Rescue Victoria overseeing stations in Wangaratta and Wodonga and the CFA reverting to a purely voluntary organisation.

Depending on which side of politics you listen to the shake-up is either the best thing to happen to fire services in Victoria in 60 years or the precursor to a massive drop in safety.

Premier Daniel Andrews says the existing "fire services structure isn't working" and his government's revamp will "protect CFA volunteers" and "keep Victorians safe, wherever they live".

But Liberal member for Northern Victoria Wendy Lovell says Mr Andrews "is ripping apart 160 years of proud history of volunteer firefighting in Victoria".

"His decision will be detrimental to volunteers and will result in a big decline in volunteer numbers, which will reduce the capacity of the CFA to fight major fires during the fire season," Ms Lovell said.

"Currently, during major fires - such as the Black Saturday fires - the surge capacity for volunteers is largely boosted by volunteers coming from outer-urban CFA stations, and these stations will no longer be part of the CFA."

At the heart of the CFA brouhaha has been a dispute over an enterprise bargaining agreement and the role of the United Firefighters Union.

The splitting of paid and volunteer firefighters is a way of resolving tensions, even if it is couched in terms of "modernising".

But is it worth irking some volunteers who are left to wonder what they've done wrong.

As the cliche goes, only time will tell.

NSW has operated with a similar model for many years with permanent crews under the Fire and Rescue moniker and volunteers part of the Rural Fire Service.

Former NSW Fire and Rescue commissioner Greg Mullins will chair a committee to oversee the new Victorian system.

Let's hope he extinguishes that metaphorical remote forest fire and helps spark a smooth-operating set-up in Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5VW8-BCY1-JD34-V539-00000-00Another burn off planned near Ballarat2019-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisAnother burn off planned near Ballarat

Days after a controlled burn in Canadian blanketed Ballarat in smoke, Forest Fire Management Victoria will undertake an 87-hectare burn at the Nerrina Heritage Area on Sunday.

Nearby residents and travellers on the Western Freeway are warned they may see smoke from the burn, which will be about six kilometres north-east of Ballarat.

Grampians region's assistant chief fire officer Tony English said it was a risk-reduction burn, "critical to providing the highest level of localised protection to human life, property and community assets in surrounding areas".

"Specifically, the burn is bounded by Glenisla Road to the east, the powerline easement that extends from Glenisla Road to the north, Forest Road to the west, and Boroka Street to the south," he said.

"Road closures will be in place at Glen Park and Glenisla Roads, and motorists are asked to avoid the area. Internal tracks within the heritage area, including the Nuggety Gully Dam Picnic Area, will be closed.

"We understand that smoke from planned burns may cause concerns for some people, but it is important that our crews take the opportunity while conditions are right.

"Before we undertake any planned burn, many factors and conditions need to perfectly align for a burn to be successful.

"A big part of this is measuring the fuel moisture content of a burn site, along with measurements of humidity, temperature and wind speed; we will only ignite the burn if conditions are suitable on the day.

"This planned burn contributes to a broader fuel management program for forest areas surrounding Ballarat."

People experiencing symptoms due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or phone NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

urn:contentItem:5T5X-X1S1-JD34-V4BC-00000-00The spring firewood collection...2018-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:29:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7The spring firewood collection...

The spring firewood collection season has opened, meaning residents can pick up wood from designated areas until November.

Hume assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse reminded gatherers to stay within collection limits.

"You may collect up to two cubic metres of firewood per person per day, and up to 16 cubic metres per household per year," he said. "This prevents households stockpiling large volumes of firewood and denying others a supply.

"Some designated firewood collection areas may not open at the beginning of the season for various reasons, including supply or accessibility due to wet conditions. Firewood collection areas that have proposed burns within them ... may be closed early or at short notice."

He said closures of firewood collection areas due to burning operations would be notified on site, at local Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning offices and on the website and DELWP Hume Facebook page if time allowed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria staff will patrol parks, forests and reserves to make sure people are doing the right thing.

"The felling of any trees for firewood is strictly prohibited and it's also illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence," Mr Hayse said.

Details: bit.ly/2qP7Mll

Esther Lauaki
